qas.question: In what year did MCA take over Universal?
What company did MCA create in 1964?
What new name was given to Revue Productions in 1966?
What was the company formed by the merger of Universal and NBC?
When did Universal inaugurate its studio tour subsidiary?
What did MAC, Inc. do in 1962?
What name did the company revert to after the MAC takeover?
What was Universal Pictures Company and Revue Productions renamed in 1966?
What television network did MCA later merge with?

context: The long-awaited <b5_0>takeover of Universal Pictures<b5_0/> by MCA, Inc. happened in mid-<a0_0>1962<a0_0/> as part of the MCA-Decca Records merger. The company reverted in name to <b6_0>Universal Pictures<b6_0/>. As a final gesture before leaving the talent agency business, virtually every MCA client was signed to a Universal contract. In <a4_0>1964<a4_0/> MCA formed <a1_0><b7_0>Universal City Studios, Inc.<b7_0/><a1_0/>, merging the motion pictures and television arms of Universal Pictures Company and Revue Productions (officially renamed as <a2_0><b8_0>Universal Television<b8_0/><a2_0/> in 1966). And so, with MCA in charge, Universal became a full-blown, A-film movie studio, with leading actors and directors under contract; offering slick, commercial films; and a studio tour subsidiary launched in 1964. Television production made up much of the studio's output, with Universal heavily committed, in particular, to deals with <b9_0>NBC<b9_0/> (which later merged with Universal to form <a3_0>NBC Universal<a3_0/>; see below) providing up to half of all prime time shows for several seasons. An innovation during this period championed by Universal was the made-for-television movie.
